Award.AwardTitle: Northern Arizona University Noyce Fellows Program

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project establishes a Noyce Fellows Program at Northern Arizona University (NAU) and builds on a recently implemented new undergraduate teacher preparation program, NAUTeach, and a new post-baccalaureate teacher preparation program for STEM professionals, the Certificate for Mathematics or Science Teachers (C-MOST). NAUTeach is an undergraduate science and mathematics teacher preparation program modeled after the UTeach program. The C-MOST program attracts STEM career changers and can be completed in three semesters in on-line or face to face formats. Across these two programs, along with the Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program, NAU has committed to graduate 80 secondary science and mathematics each year by 2013. The project is supporting 56 science and mathematics teacher candidates with $15,000 one-year stipends or scholarships. The project also includes an induction program that provides continued training and support for Noyce fellows and includes both face to face and distance-delivery formats. Furthermore, through a partnership with Mesa Community College (MCC), the NAU Noyce Fellows Program provides internships for up to 75 freshman or sophomore students each year from the Maricopa County Community College District (MCCCD) and NAU who have expressed an interest in STEM disciplines. The partnership with MCCCD provides a pipeline from the community colleges to teacher certification programs at NAU, to increase the diversity of students who pursue teaching science and mathematics, and to prepare teachers from areas in the state that are often hard pressed to employ qualified secondary science and mathematics teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NAU Noyce Fellows Program (NSF #1035495) was initiated in 2010 and considered the entire professional development continuum of secondary teachers from early exposure via internships, to teacher preparation, to inservice teaching with induction support. By supporting the entire spectrum of teacher development, the NAU Noyce Fellows Program enhanced the infrastructure for education at NAU and promoted STEM-based partnerships throughout the state of Arizona.  In addition, a supplemental Noyce grant (NSF #1000148) allowed this project to support a successful Navajo Math Circle component between 2012 and 2015. The NAU Noyce Fellows Program came to a close in August 2017.

NAU Noyce Scholarships/Stipends: The NAU Noyce Fellows Program awarded 61 scholarships/stipends to highly qualified undergraduate and graduate mathematics and science preservice teacher candidates. Approximately 18% of recipients were from underrepresented populations, a number equal to the national average for teachers (AACTE, 2013). In addition to receiving stipend or scholarship support, over 40 Noyce recipients were provided financial support to attend state, regional, and national math or science professional conferences, including regional and national Noyce conferences. Scholar retention to graduation is 98%. Fifty-seven Noyce recipients have successfully completed their teacher preparation program to date (with three more in progress), 17 (28%) with certification in math teaching and 40 (72%) with certification in science teaching. Of the 57 graduates thus far, 70% are teaching in math or science classrooms in high needs school districts in the 2017-2018 school year. Although 28% of Noyce graduates will not be teachers of record in high need public schools during the 2017-18 school year, several are still in teaching-related positions and a large majority are pursuing advanced degrees prior to entering the teaching profession.  Only 8% of Noyce graduates are pursuing non-teaching opportunities at this time.   

 

NAU Noyce Internship Program: In addition to the scholarship/stipend program, the NAU Noyce Fellows Program supported the Maricopa County Community College District (MCCCD) Math/Science Internship program. The internship program provided support for 141 undergraduate student interns at 47 math/science summer youth camp sites with 8 internship partners throughout Arizona over the course of six summers. Over 30% of interns were from underrepresented groups, higher than in the teaching profession overall. It was hoped that offering early experiences in teaching would be an effective strategy for increasing diversity in the teaching profession. Interns provided valuable support to the STEM educators running the camps, and helped facilitate positive STEM experiences to an estimated 5,800 K-12 youth. According to a follow-up survey among summer interns from years one through four, a large majority of students indicated that their Noyce summer internship influenced their decision to pursue a STEM-related career.

 

NAU Noyce Induction Program: The research-based NAU Noyce Induction program provided online and face-to-face induction support to Noyce scholars and fellows as they became early career teachers. To date, 44 Noyce graduates have participated in at least one year of the program, with 27 fellows/scholars having completed the full two-year program and 13 fellows/scholars still enrolled in year one or year two of the program. Additionally,16 non-Noyce graduates participated in one year of the induction program. Participants reported that the Noyce program gave them the support, confidence and tools to be successful and to continue to improve their teaching. Retention of induction participants in teaching is high, with only two teachers who participated in the program having taken a break from teaching at this time. The NAU Noyce Induction program fulfills an important role in scholars’ continued professional development as STEM teachers. All Noyce graduates have taken on leadership roles at their schools by their second year and some are already training or mentoring others and writing curriculum.

 

NAU Noyce Navajo Math Circle Project (NSF #1000148): The goal of the Navajo Nation Math Circle Project (NNMCP) was to develop and demonstrate the math circle concept in the Native American community in order to attract more Native Americans into STEM fields, specifically the field of mathematics. The concept of Math Circles is to bring mathematicians and mathematical scientists into direct contact with pre-college students. Participating students, and sometimes their teachers, met with mathematical professionals in an informal setting, after school or on weekends, to work on interesting problems or topics in mathematics. NNMCP project activities included professional development for over 93 teachers, an annual festival that reached over 700 students and included 40 inservice and 10 preservice teachers, and a two-week summer camp that served 34 students (15 girls and 19 boys). Math circles were held at eight schools on the Navajo Nation, with 404 middle school and high school students and their teachers participating. Eight faculty from various colleges and universities from around the nation, including NAU, participated in the program as mentors. Five NAU students, three of whom were Noyce Scholars, participated and facilitated math circles activities.
